title: Typeface Suggestions - Ones Similar to Clearface Gothic and Officina Sans
content:
I'm creating the logo for a small interior design firm. The owner preferred initial mockups in Clearface Gothic and Officina Sans over more elegant (Bodoni, Didot, Optima, Centaur, Caslon Openface etc.) and contemporary (Gill Sans, Futura, Avenir, Helvetica, Mostra) ones.

Here are my questions:

1. Do you think a font like Clearface or Officina suits such a business's identity?

2. What are some similar fonts I can consider?

Any help would be greatly appreciated.
author: TheYellowDart

comments.content: well, did the owner say what s/he liked about the clearface and officina designs?

I'm going to make a crazy guess: is the client a woman?

Clearface Gothic seems a little out of date for a creative firm. I suppose it depends on what sort of interior design they want to be known for. Officina is not too bad, more modern, but overused. I'd consider one of these, gentle and friendly like Clearface and Officina, but less common and more up-to-date:

[Cronos](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322135658/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=verity.search&searchstr=Cronos)  
 [Bryant](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322135658/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=verity.search&searchstr=Bryant)  
 [FF Strada](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322135658/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=verity.search&searchstr=Strada)  
 [FF Unit](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322135658/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=verity.search&searchstr=FF%20Unit)

<cite>I’m going to make a crazy guess: is the client a woman?</cite>

Correct you are. As a male, I was rooting for the more contemporary geometric fonts. Thanks for your suggestions, Stephen, I'll be sure to look into them.

<cite>Clearface Gothic seems a little out of date for a creative firm.</cite>

While we're on this subject, what (semi-unique, not oft-used) typefaces would all of you consider "in date" for a creative firm? Would you have chosen some of the same fonts I have written down above?

The disatvantage of using a well know typeface in a logotype, could be that the unique feeling get lost a bit. Even if the letters themselves are edited, the typeface itself is soemtimes so familiar that the overall result is too "common" or "flat".

My advise would be to find slightly less familiar typefaces to start with for the logotype.

You might something apealing at [http://www.macrhino.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322135658/http:/www.macrhino.com/ "http://www.macrhino.com")

Good luck

I agree with Stefan -- you'd be better served using a lesser known typeface for the logo if you want the logo to stand out.

For some gorgeous sans serif faces check the [Psy/Ops](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322135658/http:/www.psyops.com/html/specimens.html) catalogue. Alternatives for ITC Officina Sans could be Reykjavik which comes in a masculine ( [Herra](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322135658/http:/www.psyops.com/html/spec_reykjavik1.html)) and a feminine ( [Ungfru](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322135658/http:/www.psyops.com/html/spec_reykjavik2.html)) flavour, [Default Gothic](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322135658/http:/www.psyops.com/html/spec_default.html) which has a little more contrast and some very nice character shapes, and the very elegant and subtly feminine [Eidetic Modern](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322135658/http:/www.psyops.com/html/spec_eidetm.html),

Here's [Simon Schmidt](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322135658/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Simon%20Schmidt)'s [Hybrid](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322135658/http:/www.fountain.nu/catalogue/hybrid.asp) -- I'm specifically looking for relatively unknown, slightly condensed simple sans serifs with a subtle twist _(alliteration allert! :^D)_

One of my current favourites is [Tomas Brousil](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322135658/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Tomas%20Brousil)'s [Katarine](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322135658/http:/www.suitcasetype.com/page.php?lmut=en&section=font&font=katarine) which subtly refers to license plate lettering and sports stunning italics. [Botanika](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322135658/http:/www.suitcasetype.com/page.php?lmut=en&section=font&font=botanika) is somewhat more plain but features numerous variations.

And what about [Peter Verheul's](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322135658/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Peter%20Verheul%27s) Versa Sans, available through [OurType](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322135658/http:/www.ourtype.be/)?

Or [Jean François Porchez](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322135658/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Jean%20Fran%C3%A7ois%20Porchez)'s sensuous (and fully featured OpenType!) [Costa PTF](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322135658/http:/www.typofonderie.com/alphabets/view/CostaPTF)?

ok, i'll jump on the bandwagon:  
 [Sebastian](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322135658/http:/www.stormtype.com/typefaces-fonts-shop/index.php?id=42)  
 [John Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322135658/http:/www.stormtype.com/typefaces-fonts-shop/index.php?id=23)  
 [Metron](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322135658/http:/www.stormtype.com/typefaces-fonts-shop/index.php?id=29)  
 [Amor Sans](http://web.archive.org/)

<cite>Metron</cite>

How looking at something like that can make my heart pound is something I can't explain, but it makes me feel strange. (wondering if perhaps I should seek counseling...)  
: )

It's ok to love fonts. Just don't LOVE fonts.
